words.definition: Accept something reluctantly but without protest.
examples: She acquiesced to their demands despite reservations.
The board acquiesced to the CEO's proposal.

words.definition: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
examples: She accepted the challenge with alacrity.
The team responded with alacrity to the emergency.

words.definition: Something belonging to a period other than that depicted.
examples: A computer in a medieval painting would be an anachronism.
The word processor is an anachronism in modern offices.

words.definition: Showing a willingness to take bold risks.
examples: The audacious plan surprised everyone.
Her audacious behavior shocked the committee.

words.definition: Hostile and aggressive.
examples: The belligerent customer was asked to leave.
His belligerent attitude escalated the conflict.

words.definition: Noisy, energetic, and cheerful.
examples: The boisterous crowd celebrated the victory.
Boisterous laughter filled the room.

words.definition: Showing or having an insensitive disregard for others.
examples: His callous remarks hurt her feelings.
The callous treatment of workers was condemned.

words.definition: The quality of being open and honest in expression.
examples: I appreciate your candor in this discussion.
She spoke with refreshing candor.

words.definition: Showing contempt; scornful.
examples: She gave him a contemptuous look.
His contemptuous attitude alienated colleagues.

words.definition: In keeping with good taste and propriety.
examples: They maintained decorous behavior at the funeral.
The decorous ceremony honored tradition.

words.definition: Modest or shy because of lack of self-confidence.
examples: The diffident student rarely spoke in class.
His diffident manner belied his expertise.

words.definition: Perceive or recognize something.
examples: She could discern the truth in his words.
It's hard to discern details in dim light.

words.definition: Fluent or persuasive speaking or writing.
examples: The lawyer's eloquence swayed the jury.
Her eloquence impressed the audience.

words.definition: Make something more attractive by adding decorative details.
examples: She embellished the story with dramatic details.
The dress was embellished with sequins.

words.definition: Things that exist or are used for only a short time.
examples: The museum collected historical ephemera.
Concert tickets are considered ephemera.

words.definition: The quality of being sociable and enjoying company.
examples: His gregariousness made him popular at parties.
The dog's gregariousness was endearing.

words.definition: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.
examples: Robins are harbingers of spring.
The dark clouds were a harbinger of the storm.

words.definition: Arrogantly superior and disdainful.
examples: Her haughty manner offended everyone.
The haughty aristocrat looked down on commoners.

words.definition: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
examples: The iconoclast challenged traditional views.
She was an iconoclast in her field.

words.definition: Acting quickly without thought or care.
examples: His impetuous decision had consequences.
The impetuous youth rushed into danger.

words.definition: Feeling or showing anger at unfair treatment.
examples: She was indignant at the accusation.
The indignant customer demanded a refund.

words.definition: Displaying or having a lack of energy or vitality.
examples: The languid afternoon heat made everyone drowsy.
She gave a languid wave from the hammock.

words.definition: Easily influenced; able to be hammered into shape.
examples: Young minds are malleable and impressionable.
Gold is a malleable metal.

words.definition: Wicked or criminal.
examples: The villain's nefarious plot was foiled.
He had a nefarious reputation.

words.definition: Excessively concerned with minor details or rules.
examples: The pedantic professor corrected every small error.
Her pedantic approach frustrated students.

words.definition: Spending money recklessly; wasteful.
examples: The prodigal son wasted his inheritance.
His prodigal spending led to bankruptcy.

words.definition: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
examples: He was reticent about his personal life.
The reticent witness provided little information.

words.definition: Enduring pain without complaint; unemotional.
examples: She remained stoic throughout the ordeal.
His stoic demeanor masked his emotions.

words.definition: Sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
examples: His terse reply suggested annoyance.
The terse note conveyed the message clearly.

words.definition: Suave, courteous, and refined in manner.
examples: His urbane manners impressed everyone.
The urbane host made guests feel welcome.
